1 Introdution

Thus far, we have computed the electric field without using Gauss’s law, but the geometry and symmetry of the systems considered are such that Gauss’s law applies.

1.1 Definition of D \mathbf{D} D and Derivation of Gauss’ Law for Dielectrics

We have shown that induced dipoles will form when an electric field exists in a dielectric. The electric field at a given location in the dielectric depends on the electric field due to all of the other dipoles and the external electric field. So, as it stands, to compute the electric field in a dielectric … you need to know the electric field in the dielectric.

One way of resolving this is to assume that the electric field in a dielectric is reduced by a factor of what it would have been if the dielectric was not there. This is only sometimes correct and is thus about as useful as the grammar rule “i before e except after c”.

Gauss’ Law can be used to find the correct answer for certain problems (the same types of problems where it is useful for calculating the electric field - problems with symmetry that allows simplification of the integral). More generally, special techniques are needed (Boundary Value Method and the Method of Images), both of which rely of Gauss’ Law for dielectrics.

We being by first defining a new quantity related to E \mathbf{E} E, the oddly named electric displacement or electric flux density*, D \mathbf{D} D, which is also called the electric flux density,

D ≡ ϵ 0 E + P \mathbf{D}\equiv\epsilon_0\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P} D≡ϵ0​E+P

E \mathbf{E} E is the electric field, which is due to external electric fields and the electric field of the induced dipoles. P \mathbf{P} P is the polarization, which depends on E \mathbf{E} E. We are combining two things that are difficult to calculate to define D \mathbf{D} D, which perhaps unexpectedly, will be easier to calculate.

We also distinguish charges among those that are due to polarization, Q b o u n d Q_{bound} Qbound​, and the rest, Q f r e e Q_{free} Qfree​ (again, naming choice could be clearer, but is standard):

Q = Q f r e e + Q b o u n d Q = Q_{free} + Q_{bound} Q=Qfree​+Qbound​

Next, write Gauss’ Law in terms of D \mathbf{D} D, P \mathbf{P} P, Q f r e e Q_{free} Qfree​, and Q b o u n d Q_{bound} Qbound​:

Gauss’ Law is

Φ E ≡ ∮ S E ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S / ϵ 0 \Phi_E\equiv\oint_{S} \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S}/\epsilon_0 ΦE​≡∮S​E⋅da=QInside,S​/ϵ0​

substitution gives

∮ S ( D / ϵ 0 − P / ϵ 0 ) ⋅ d a = Q F r e e , i n s i d e , S / ϵ 0 + Q B o u n d , i n s i d e , S / ϵ 0 \oint_{S} (\mathbf{D}/\epsilon_0 - \mathbf{P}/\epsilon_0) \cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Free,inside,S}/\epsilon_0 + Q_{Bound,inside,S}/\epsilon_0 ∮S​(D/ϵ0​−P/ϵ0​)⋅da=QFree,inside,S​/ϵ0​+QBound,inside,S​/ϵ0​

simplifying

∮ S D ⋅ d a − ∮ S P ⋅ d a = Q F r e e , i n s i d e , S + Q B o u n d , i n s i d e , S \oint_{S} \mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} - \oint_{S}\mathbf{P}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Free,inside,S}+ Q_{Bound,inside,S} ∮S​D⋅da−∮S​P⋅da=QFree,inside,S​+QBound,inside,S​

The second term on both sides of the equation are equal*, leaving

∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

This is another form of Gauss’ Law and is referred to here as Gauss’ Law for dielectrics in integral form. It is also valid for non-dielectrics. In older textbooks, one often finds a discussion of electric displacement flux, Φ D \Phi_D ΦD​

Φ D ≡ ∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \Phi_D\equiv\oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ΦD​≡∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

before the electric flux

Φ E ≡ ∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S \Phi_E\equiv\oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S} ΦE​≡∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S​

The equation for Φ D \Phi_D ΦD​ looks similar to that for Φ E \Phi_E ΦE​, except that its right-hand side only refers to non-bound charges (“free charges”) inside a surface and the factor of ϵ 0 \epsilon_0 ϵ0​ is missing. The equations for Φ E \Phi_E ΦE​ and Φ D \Phi_D ΦD​ are equally valid, but Φ D \Phi_D ΦD​ should be used for dielectrics as it simplifies the solution.

*Using σ b = P ⋅ n ^ \sigma_b = \mathbf{P}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}} σb​=P⋅n^ and d a ≡ n ^ d a d\mathbf{a}\equiv \hat{\mathbf{n}}da da≡n^da gives

− ∮ S P ⋅ d a = − ∮ S P ⋅ n ^ d a = − ∮ S σ b d a -\oint_{S}\mathbf{P}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = -\oint_{S}\mathbf{P}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{n}}da = -\oint_{S}\sigma_bda −∮S​P⋅da=−∮S​P⋅n^da=−∮S​σb​da

σ b \sigma_b σb​ refers to charges ‘’on’’, but not inside of, a Gaussian surface. Because we are talking about dipoles, there must be an equal an opposite number of charges just below, and so inside, the Gaussian surface. So Q B o u n d , e n c l o s e d = − ∮ S σ b d a Q_{Bound,enclosed} = -\oint_{S}\sigma_bda QBound,enclosed​=−∮S​σb​da.

1.2 Historical Origin and Units on D \mathbf{D} D

The units on electric displacement are

[ D ] = Coulomb m 2 [\mathbf{D}]=\frac{\text{Coulomb}}{\text{m}^2} [D]=m2Coulomb​

whereas for electric field

[ E ] = Newtons Coulomb [\mathbf{E}]=\frac{\text{Newtons}}{\text{Coulomb}} [E]=CoulombNewtons​

In a sense, D \mathbf{D} D is more natural quantity with regard to its units - because the units in its denominator are m 2 m^2 m2, it ‘’seems’’ like a quantity that you would want to integrate over an area. But then this leads to the awkward question of “Flux is usually a quantity fo ‘stuff’ flowing through a surface”. According to Gauss’ Law for dielectrics, the ‘stuff’ has units of coulombs. But no actual charge flows through the surface?!” When the laws of electricity were being formulated, Faraday, Maxwell and others were very much influenced by the physics of fluid flow. The word “flux” means flow. In Faraday’s 1837 experiment, he noted that it was if charge was induced on the outer sphere and was displaced by lines of force originating on the inner sphere. [https://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/Rarebook_treasures/QC503F211839_PDF/QC503F211839v2.pdf] [https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page%3AA_Treatise_on_Electricity_and_Magnetism_-_Volume_1.djvu/100 First reference of Maxwell to “displacement”]

See also http://www.jpier.org/PIER/pier149/17.14092503.pdf

This is one of the many reasons why E&M is conceptually difficult. Consider Lord Kelvin’s opinion: “That is why I take plain dynamics. I can get a model in plain dynamics; I cannot in electromagnetics.” [http://zapatopi.net/kelvin/quotes/]. Also “I have not had a moment’s peace or happiness in respect to electromagnetic theory since Nov. 28 1846.” [https://books.google.com/books?id=mN0TDAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA229&ots=mlKk9PJkji&dq=Nov.%2028%201846%20Faraday%20publication&pg=PA229#v=onepage&q=Nov.%2028%201846%20Faraday%20publication&f=false]. See [https://books.google.com/books?id=kdm9nmAkKvIC&lpg=PA1015&dq=November%2028%201846%20kelvin&pg=PA1015#v=onepage&q=November%2028%201846%20kelvin&f=false] for the relevance of the date.”

2 Using Gauss’ Law for Dielectrics

Here is how Gauss’ Law has can be used to resolve the issue for certain types of problems. First, compute D \mathbf{D} D using Gauss’ Law for dielectrics. The charges in this version of the law refer to charges that we usually know about - their location and magnitude (this is the motivation for calling them “free” - we can freely, or at least more easily, modify their location and magnitude). Then, use P = χ e ϵ 0 E \mathbf{P}=\chi_e\epsilon_0\mathbf{E} P=χe​ϵ0​E and the definition of D \mathbf{D} D

D ≡ ϵ 0 E + P = ϵ 0 E + χ e ϵ 0 E \mathbf{D}\equiv\epsilon_0\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{P}=\epsilon_0\mathbf{E}+\chi_e\epsilon_0\mathbf{E} D≡ϵ0​E+P=ϵ0​E+χe​ϵ0​E

and solve for E \mathbf{E} E

E = D ϵ 0 ( 1 + χ e ) \mathbf{E}=\frac{\mathbf{D}}{\epsilon_0(1+\chi_e)} E=ϵ0​(1+χe​)D​

Another common way of writing this is

E = D / ϵ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon E=D/ϵ

using the definition

ϵ = ≡ ϵ 0 ( 1 + χ e ) \epsilon=\equiv\epsilon_0(1+\chi_e) ϵ=≡ϵ0​(1+χe​)

ϵ ϵ 0 = ϵ r ≡ ( 1 + χ e ) \frac{\epsilon}{\epsilon_0}=\epsilon_r\equiv(1+\chi_e) ϵ0​ϵ​=ϵr​≡(1+χe​)

They are a measure of the magnitude of the dielectric permittivity relative to the permittivity of free space.

To complicate matters, some references use dielectric constant κ \kappa κ or relative permittivity κ r \kappa_r κr​ instead of ϵ \epsilon ϵ and ϵ r \epsilon_r ϵr​.

2.1 Problems

2.1.1 Dielectric Between Sheets of Charge

An infinite non-conducting sheet in the x = d x=d x=d plane has a charge density of − σ 0 -\sigma_0 −σ0​; An infinite non-conducting sheet in the x = − d x=-d x=−d plane has a charge density of + σ 0 +\sigma_0 +σ0​, where σ 0 > 0 \sigma_0>0 σ0​>0. (That is, the sheet in the x = d x=d x=d plane is negatively charged and the sheet in the x = − d x=-d x=−d plane is positively charged.)

Label key points on your plots in terms of σ 0 , d \sigma_0, d σ0​,d, and ϵ 0 \epsilon_0 ϵ0​. A diagram is given on the board.

  1. Plot the electric field as a function of x x x from x = − 2 d x=-2d x=−2d to x = + 2 d x=+2d x=+2d.

  2. Plot the electric potential as a function of x x x from x = − 2 d x=-2d x=−2d to x = + 2 d x=+2d x=+2d. Set the electric potential to zero at x = 0 x=0 x=0.

{| class=”wikitable collapsible collapsed” ! align=”left” | Answer |- | Each sheet produces an electric field with magnitude σ 0 / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) \sigma_0/(2\epsilon_0) σ0​/(2ϵ0​). Electric field lines point towards negative sheet and away from the positive sheet. Because we are treating sheets are infinite, the electric field does not depend on distance from the sheet and electric field is perpendicular to the sheet. Because the sheets have equal and opposite charge, the electric field sums to zero in the regions x < − d x<-d x<−d and x > d x>d x>d. Between the sheets, the electric fields add and are both in the + x ^ +\hat{\mathbf{x}} +x^-direction.

  • x < − d x < -d x<−d, E = 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=0x^

  • − d < x < − d -d < x < -d −d<x<−d, E = + σ 0 / ϵ 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=+\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=+σ0​/ϵ0​x^

  • x > d x > d x>d, E = 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=0x^

We expect the electric potential to be the highest near the positive sheet as this is the location where a positive test charge will have the highest potential energy. We are given the potential at x = 0 x=0 x=0 - a reference potential must always be given or specified because differences in potential are what determine physical quantities of interest. We can approach this problem in two ways:

  1. Ask what V V V would give the correct E \mathbf{E} E when we use E = − ∇ V = − x ^ ∂ V / ∂ x \mathbf{E}=-\nabla V = -\hat{\mathbf{x}}\partial V/\partial x E=−∇V=−x^∂V/∂x

  2. Use Δ V = − ∫ a b E ⋅ d l \Delta V=-\int_a^b \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{l} ΔV=−∫ab​E⋅dl

From 1., we conclude that V V V must be linear with a negative slope of σ 0 / ϵ 0 \sigma_0/\epsilon_0 σ0​/ϵ0​ between the sheets and it must be constant (and not necessarily zero) outside of the sheets. The given V ( 0 ) = 0 V(0)=0 V(0)=0 give the intercept as 0 0 0. The electric potential must be continuous and it does not change for x < − d x<-d x<−d and x > d x>d x>d because the electric field is zero. So for x < − d x<-d x<−d, the potential must be the same as it is at x = − d x=-d x=−d and similar for x > d x>d x>d. These considerations give

  • x < − d x < -d x<−d, V = σ 0 d / ϵ 0 V=\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V=σ0​d/ϵ0​

  • − d < x < − d -d < x < -d −d<x<−d, V = − σ 0 x / ϵ 0 V=-\sigma_0x/\epsilon_0 V=−σ0​x/ϵ0​

  • x > d x > d x>d, V = − σ 0 d / ϵ 0 V=-\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V=−σ0​d/ϵ0​

The second approach is to use δ V = V ( b ) − V ( a ) = − ∫ a b E ⋅ d l \delta V= V(b)-V(a) = -\int_a^b \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{l} δV=V(b)−V(a)=−∫ab​E⋅dl in the different regions. In all regions, d l = x ^ d x d\mathbf{l}=\hat{\mathbf{x}}dx dl=x^dx. Choosing a = 0 a=0 a=0 and b = x b=x b=x, we have

Δ V = V ( b ) − V ( a ) = V ( x ) − V ( 0 ) = − ∫ 0 x + σ 0 / ϵ 0 x ^ ′ ⋅ x ^ ′ d x ′ = − σ 0 x / ϵ 0 \Delta V = V(b)-V(a) = V(x)-V(0)=-\int_0^x +\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}}'\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}'dx'=-\sigma_0x/\epsilon_0 ΔV=V(b)−V(a)=V(x)−V(0)=−∫0x​+σ0​/ϵ0​x^′⋅x^′dx′=−σ0​x/ϵ0​

where x ^ ⋅ x ^ = 1 \hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{x}}=1 x^⋅x^=1 has been used and the dummy integration variable was set to x ′ x' x′. Since V ( 0 ) = 0 V(0)=0 V(0)=0, we have, V ( x ) = − σ 0 x / ϵ 0 V(x)=-\sigma_0x/\epsilon_0 V(x)=−σ0​x/ϵ0​, which applies only to the region for which E = + σ 0 / ϵ 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=+\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=+σ0​/ϵ0​x^. This equation can be used to find V ( d ) = − σ 0 d / ϵ 0 V(d)=-\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V(d)=−σ0​d/ϵ0​ and V ( − d ) = σ 0 d / ϵ 0 V(-d)=\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V(−d)=σ0​d/ϵ0​. To find the potential for x > d x>d x>d, we can use

Δ V = V ( x ) − V ( d ) = − ∫ d x 0 x ^ ′ ⋅ x ^ ′ d x ′ = 0 \Delta V=V(x)-V(d)=-\int_d^x 0\hat{\mathbf{x}}'\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}'dx'=0 ΔV=V(x)−V(d)=−∫dx​0x^′⋅x^′dx′=0

so that V ( x ) = V ( d ) V(x)=V(d) V(x)=V(d) for x > d x>d x>d. Similarily, for x < − d x<-d x<−d

Δ V = V ( x ) − V ( − d ) = − ∫ − d x 0 x ^ ′ ⋅ x ^ ′ d x ′ = 0 \Delta V=V(x)-V(-d)=-\int_{-d}^x 0\hat{\mathbf{x}}'\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}'dx'=0 ΔV=V(x)−V(−d)=−∫−dx​0x^′⋅x^′dx′=0

giving V ( x ) = V ( − d ) = σ 0 d / ϵ 0 V(x)=V(-d)=\sigma_0d/\epsilon_0 V(x)=V(−d)=σ0​d/ϵ0​. |}

2.1.2 Dielectric Next to a Sheet of Charge

A dielectric of thickness t t t is placed next to a sheet of charge with charge density σ o \sigma_o σo​.

As a function of distance from the sheet,

  1. Plot the electric displacement, D D D

  2. Plot the electric field, E E E

  3. Plot the electric potential, V V V

{| class=”wikitable collapsible collapsed” ! align=”left” | Answer |- | We proceed as if the dielectric is not there.

Draw a Gaussian cylinder as shown in the figure. We seek to find

Left cap: D = − D x ^ \mathbf{D}=-D\hat{\mathbf{x}} D=−Dx^

Right cap: D = D x ^ \mathbf{D}=D\hat{\mathbf{x}} D=Dx^

From the diagram,

Left cap: d a = − d a x ^ d\mathbf{a}=-da\hat{\mathbf{x}} da=−dax^

Right cap: d a = d a x ^ d\mathbf{a}=da\hat{\mathbf{x}} da=dax^

and

Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = σ o A Q_{Inside,S,free}=\sigma_oA QInside,S,free​=σo​A

Gauss’ Law for dielectric is

∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

Expanding the surface integral into three parts gives

∮ L e f t , c a p D ⋅ d a + ∮ R i g h t , c a p D ⋅ d a + ∮ S i d e D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{Left,cap}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a}+\oint_{Right,cap}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a}+\oint_{Side}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮Left,cap​D⋅da+∮Right,cap​D⋅da+∮Side​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

Plugging in D \mathbf{D} D and d A d\mathbf{A} dA and Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = σ o A Q_{Inside,S,free}=\sigma_oA QInside,S,free​=σo​A and noting that on the side, D \mathbf{D} D is perpendicular to d a d\mathbf{a} da, so their dot product is 0 d a 0da 0da gives

∮ L e f t , c a p D x ^ ⋅ d a x ^ + ∮ R i g h t , c a p − D x ^ ⋅ ( − d a x ^ ) + ∮ S i d e 0 d a = σ o A \oint_{Left,cap}D\hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\oint_{Right,cap}-D\hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot (-da\hat{\mathbf{x}})+\oint_{Side}0da = \sigma_oA ∮Left,cap​Dx^⋅dax^+∮Right,cap​−Dx^⋅(−dax^)+∮Side​0da=σo​A

D D D is constant on the caps, so it can be factored out of the integral

D ∮ L e f t , c a p x ^ ⋅ d a x ^ + D ∮ R i g h t , c a p x ^ ⋅ d a x ^ + 0 = σ o A D\oint_{Left,cap}\hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{x}}+D\oint_{Right,cap}\hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{x}}+0 = \sigma_oA D∮Left,cap​x^⋅dax^+D∮Right,cap​x^⋅dax^+0=σo​A

Further simplifcation can be done by noting that x ^ ⋅ x ^ = 1 \hat{\mathbf{x}}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{x}}=1 x^⋅x^=1

Leaving

D ∮ L e f t , c a p d a + D ∮ R i g h t , c a p d a + 0 = σ o A D\oint_{Left,cap}da+D\oint_{Right,cap}da+0 = \sigma_oA D∮Left,cap​da+D∮Right,cap​da+0=σo​A

Integration gives

+ D A − D A = σ o A +DA-DA=\sigma_oA +DA−DA=σo​A

Solving for D D D gives

D = σ o / 2 D=\sigma_o/2 D=σo​/2

Inserting this magnitude for D \mathbf{D} D into the original equations gives

Left side: D = − D x ^ = − σ o / 2 x ^ \mathbf{D}=-D\hat{\mathbf{x}}=-\sigma_o/2\hat{\mathbf{x}} D=−Dx^=−σo​/2x^

Right side: D = D x ^ = σ o / 2 x ^ \mathbf{D}=D\hat{\mathbf{x}}=\sigma_o/2\hat{\mathbf{x}} D=Dx^=σo​/2x^

In a dielectric in general,

E = D / ϵ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon E=D/ϵ

so that

Left side: E = D / ϵ = − σ o / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) x ^ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon=-\sigma_o/(2\epsilon_0)\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=D/ϵ=−σo​/(2ϵ0​)x^

Right side: E = D / ϵ = σ o / ( 2 ϵ ) x ^ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon=\sigma_o/(2\epsilon)\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=D/ϵ=σo​/(2ϵ)x^ |}

2.1.3 Dielectric Between Sheets of Charge

Label key points on your plots in terms of σ 0 , d , ϵ 0 \sigma_0, d,\epsilon_0 σ0​,d,ϵ0​, and t t t.

An infinite linear dielectric with thickness t t t and dielectric constant ϵ / ϵ 0 = ϵ r \epsilon/\epsilon_0=\epsilon_r ϵ/ϵ0​=ϵr​ (some books use κ r \kappa_r κr​) is placed in the x = 0 x=0 x=0 plane between the two non-conducting sheets.

  1. Plot the electric field as a function of x x x from x = − 2 d x=-2d x=−2d to x = + 2 d x=+2d x=+2d.

  2. Plot the electric potential as a function of x x x from x = − 2 d x=-2d x=−2d to x = + 2 d x=+2d x=+2d. Set the electric potential to zero at x = 0 x=0 x=0. ‘’Draw trends - no axis labels needed.’’

  3. What is the induced surface charge density on

    1. the left side of the dielectric?;

    2. the right side of the dielectric?

The electric field in the dielectric is reduced because the induced surface charges produce an electric field that opposes the external electric field.

4. What is the induced electric field in the dielectric?

{| class=”wikitable collapsible collapsed” ! align=”left” | Answer |- |

D = σ o x ^ D=\sigma_o\hat{\mathbf{x}} D=σo​x^ for − d < x < d -d<x<d −d<x<d, zero otherwise.

In the dielectric,

E = D / ϵ = ( σ o / ( ϵ 0 ϵ r ) x ^ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon=(\sigma_o/(\epsilon_0\epsilon_r)\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=D/ϵ=(σo​/(ϵ0​ϵr​)x^

  • x < − d x<-d x<−d, E = 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=0x^

  • − d < x < − t / 2 -d<x<-t/2 −d<x<−t/2, E = σ 0 / ϵ 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=σ0​/ϵ0​x^

  • − t / 2 < x < t / 2 -t/2<x<t/2 −t/2<x<t/2, E = σ 0 / ( ϵ r ϵ 0 ) x ^ \mathbf{E}=\sigma_0/(\epsilon_r\epsilon_0)\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=σ0​/(ϵr​ϵ0​)x^

  • t / 2 < x < d t/2<x<d t/2<x<d, E = σ 0 / ϵ 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=\sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=σ0​/ϵ0​x^

  • x > d x>d x>d, E = 0 x ^ \mathbf{E}=0\hat{\mathbf{x}} E=0x^

Potential will be highest at + sheet, constant to the left and linearly decreasing to the right. Will decrease slower in the dielectric. Must pass through zero since V ( 0 ) = 0 V(0)=0 V(0)=0 given. Will be constant for x > d x>d x>d.

Gauss’ Law can be used with Gaussian cylinder with one cap at x < t / 2 x<t/2 x<t/2 and the other at x > t / 2 x>t/2 x>t/2. Gives σ P , R i g h t = σ o ( 1 − 1 / ϵ r ) \sigma_{P,Right}=\sigma_o(1-1/\epsilon_r) σP,Right​=σo​(1−1/ϵr​). For ϵ r → ∞ \epsilon_r \rightarrow \infty ϵr​→∞, σ P , R i g h t → σ o \sigma_{P,Right}\rightarrow\sigma_o σP,Right​→σo​ as expected (dielectric is like a conductor - electric field inside is zero when ϵ r > > 1 \epsilon_r >> 1 ϵr​>>1. By charge conservation, σ P , L e f t = − σ P , R i g h t \sigma_{P,Left}=-\sigma_{P,Right} σP,Left​=−σP,Right​. Induced electric field can be computed by treating surfaces of dielectric as sheets of charge so that E p = ( σ P , R i g h t / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) + σ P , L e f t / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) = ( σ o / ϵ 0 ) ( 1 − 1 / ϵ r ) E_p=(\sigma_{P,Right}/(2\epsilon_0)+\sigma_{P,Left}/(2\epsilon_0)=(\sigma_o/\epsilon_0)(1-1/\epsilon_r) Ep​=(σP,Right​/(2ϵ0​)+σP,Left​/(2ϵ0​)=(σo​/ϵ0​)(1−1/ϵr​). Or, one can write

E o + E p = E r \mathbf{E}_o + \mathbf{E}_p = \mathbf{E}_r Eo​+Ep​=Er​

σ 0 / ϵ 0 x ^ + E p = σ 0 / ( ϵ r ϵ 0 ) x ^ \sigma_0/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} + \mathbf{E}_p =\sigma_0/(\epsilon_r\epsilon_0)\hat{\mathbf{x}} σ0​/ϵ0​x^+Ep​=σ0​/(ϵr​ϵ0​)x^

giving

E p = − ( σ o / ϵ 0 ) ( 1 − 1 / ϵ r ) x ^ \mathbf{E}_p=-(\sigma_o/\epsilon_0)(1-1/\epsilon_r)\hat{\mathbf{x}} Ep​=−(σo​/ϵ0​)(1−1/ϵr​)x^

Check - when ϵ r → ∞ \epsilon_r\rightarrow \infty ϵr​→∞, expect polarization field to be equal and opposite to E o = ( σ o / ϵ 0 ) x ^ \mathbf{E}_o=(\sigma_o/\epsilon_0)\hat{\mathbf{x}} Eo​=(σo​/ϵ0​)x^. |}

2.1.4 Dielectric Around Cylindrical Shell of Charge

A cylindrical shell with radius a a a has a charge density σ o \sigma_o σo​ on its surface. It is surrounded by a dielectric with inner radius a a a and outer radius b b b.

  1. Draw a Gaussian cylinder with radius ρ < a \rho<a ρ<a and use it to compute D \mathbf{D} D for ρ < a \rho<a ρ<a

  2. Draw a Gaussian cylinder with radius a < ρ < b a<\rho<b a<ρ<b and use it to compute D \mathbf{D} D for a < ρ < b a <\rho < b a<ρ<b

  3. Compute and plot D \mathbf{D} D versus ρ \rho ρ. Label key points on the plot.

  4. Compute and plot E \mathbf{E} E versus ρ \rho ρ. Label key points on the plot.

  5. Compute and plot V V V versus ρ \rho ρ. Label key points on the plot.

{| class=”wikitable collapsible collapsed” ! align=”left” | Answer |- | The Gaussian cylinders are shown in the figure. On the left end cap, d a = π ρ 2 z ^ d\mathbf{a}=\pi \rho^2\hat{\mathbf{z}} da=πρ2z^ while on the right it is d a = − π ρ 2 z ^ d\mathbf{a}=-\pi\rho^2\hat{\mathbf{z}} da=−πρ2z^.

Because the charged cylinder is infinite in length, for each point on the Gaussian cylinder, a charge on the left will have a charge on the right that cancels the horizontal component of D \mathbf{D} D on the Gaussian cylinder. So D \mathbf{D} D will only be in the ρ ^ \hat{\mathbf{\rho}} ρ^​ direction.

Left cap: D = D ρ ρ ^ \mathbf{D}=D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} D=Dρ​ρ^​

Right cap: D = D ρ ρ ^ \mathbf{D}=D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} D=Dρ​ρ^​

Side: D = D ρ ρ ^ \mathbf{D}=D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} D=Dρ​ρ^​

From the diagram,

Left cap: d a = d a ρ ^ d\mathbf{a}=da\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} da=daρ^​

Right cap: d a = d a ρ ^ d\mathbf{a}=da\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} da=daρ^​

Side: d a = 2 π ρ L ρ ^ d\mathbf{a}=2\pi\rho L\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} da=2πρLρ^​

and

Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = 0 Q_{Inside,S,free}=0 QInside,S,free​=0 when ρ < a \rho < a ρ<a

Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = σ o 2 π a L Q_{Inside,S,free}=\sigma_o2\pi a L QInside,S,free​=σo​2πaL when ρ > a \rho > a ρ>a

Gauss’ Law for a dielectric is

∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

Expanding the surface integral into three parts gives

∮ L e f t , c a p D ⋅ d a + ∮ R i g h t , c a p D ⋅ d a + ∮ S i d e D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{Left,cap}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a}+\oint_{Right,cap}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a}+\oint_{Side}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮Left,cap​D⋅da+∮Right,cap​D⋅da+∮Side​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

Plugging in values for D \mathbf{D} D and d a d\mathbf{a} da gives

∮ L e f t , c a p D ρ ρ ^ ⋅ d a z ^ + ∮ R i g h t , c a p D ρ ρ ^ ⋅ d a z ^ + ∮ S i d e D ρ ρ ^ ⋅ d a ρ ^ = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{Left,cap}D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{z}}+\oint_{Right,cap} D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{z}}+\oint_{Side}D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮Left,cap​Dρ​ρ^​⋅daz^+∮Right,cap​Dρ​ρ^​⋅daz^+∮Side​Dρ​ρ^​⋅daρ^​=QInside,S,free​

The first two terms are zero because, ρ ^ ⋅ z ^ = 0 \hat{\mathbf{\rho}}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{z}}=0 ρ^​⋅z^=0, leaving

∮ S i d e D ρ ρ ^ ⋅ d a ρ ^ = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{Side}D_\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}\cdot da\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮Side​Dρ​ρ^​⋅daρ^​=QInside,S,free​

Further simplification can be done by noting that ρ ^ ⋅ ρ ^ = 1 \hat{\mathbf{\rho}}\cdot \hat{\mathbf{\rho}}=1 ρ^​⋅ρ^​=1 and that D ρ D_{\rho} Dρ​ is constant on the side of the Gaussian surface, leaving

D ρ ∮ S i d e d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e D_\rho\oint_{Side}da =Q_{Inside,S,free} Dρ​∮Side​da=QInside,S,free​

The surface area of the Gaussian cylinder is 2 π ρ L 2\pi \rho L 2πρL, giving

D ρ 2 π ρ L = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e D_\rho 2\pi \rho L = Q_{Inside,S,free} Dρ​2πρL=QInside,S,free​

When ρ < a \rho<a ρ<a, Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = 0 Q_{Inside,S,free}=0 QInside,S,free​=0, so D ρ = 0 D_\rho=0 Dρ​=0.

When ρ < a \rho<a ρ<a, Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = σ o 2 π a L Q_{Inside,S,free}=\sigma_o2\pi a L QInside,S,free​=σo​2πaL, giving

D ρ = σ o ( a / ρ ) D_\rho = \sigma_o (a/\rho) Dρ​=σo​(a/ρ)

Note that the units of D ρ D_{\rho} Dρ​ are C / m 2 C/m^2 C/m2, as expected.

  • D = 0 \mathbf{D} = 0 D=0 for ρ < a \rho<a ρ<a

  • D = σ o ( a / ρ ) ρ ^ \mathbf{D} = \sigma_o (a/\rho)\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} D=σo​(a/ρ)ρ^​ for ρ > a \rho>a ρ>a

Note that we do not have a separate equation for D \mathbf{D} D for ρ > b \rho>b ρ>b because the amount of free charge enclosed by a Gaussian cylinder does not change as its radius is increased above ρ = a \rho=a ρ=a.

To compute the electric field in the regions, we use E = D / ϵ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon E=D/ϵ, where ϵ \epsilon ϵ is the dielectric constant in each region.

  • E = 0 \mathbf{E} = 0 E=0 for ρ < a \rho<a ρ<a

  • E = ( σ o / ϵ ) ( a / ρ ) ρ ^ \mathbf{E} = (\sigma_o/\epsilon)(a/\rho)\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} E=(σo​/ϵ)(a/ρ)ρ^​ for a < ρ < b a < \rho < b a<ρ<b

  • E = ( σ o / ϵ 0 ) ( a / ρ ) ρ ^ \mathbf{E} = (\sigma_o/\epsilon_0)(a/\rho)\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} E=(σo​/ϵ0​)(a/ρ)ρ^​ for ρ > b \rho > b ρ>b

Note that the electric field “jumps” at each location that there is a free charge or a polarization charge, e.g., ρ = a \rho=a ρ=a and ρ = b \rho=b ρ=b. This is expected - think about moving from one side of a sheet of charge to the other. The change in E \mathbf{E} E is σ o / ϵ 0 \sigma_o/\epsilon_0 σo​/ϵ0​ (from - σ o / ϵ 0 x ^ \sigma_o/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} σo​/ϵ0​x^ to + σ o / ϵ 0 x ^ +\sigma_o/\epsilon_0\hat{\mathbf{x}} +σo​/ϵ0​x^).

To compute the electric potential, we first choose V = 0 V=0 V=0 at ρ = 0 \rho=0 ρ=0. The electric field is zero from ρ = 0 \rho=0 ρ=0 to ρ = a \rho=a ρ=a, so the potential does not change in this range.

Δ V = V f i n a l − V i n i t i a l = − ∫ i n i t i a l f i n a l E ⋅ d l \Delta V = V_{final}-V_{initial} = -\int_{initial}^{final} \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{l} ΔV=Vfinal​−Vinitial​=−∫initialfinal​E⋅dl

Although the change in potential from an initial location to a final location does not depend on path, we choose the most direct path as it reduces the amount of calculation. The direct path is with d l = d ρ ρ ^ d\mathbf{l}=d\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} dl=dρρ^​. The equation for potential is found by setting the initial location as a location where we know the potential and the final location as a variable:

For a < ρ < b a < \rho < b a<ρ<b, σ o / ϵ ) ( a / ρ ) ρ ^ \sigma_o/\epsilon)(a/\rho)\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} σo​/ϵ)(a/ρ)ρ^​ and V ( a ) = 0 V(a)=0 V(a)=0

Δ V = V ( ρ ) − V ( a ) = − ∫ a ρ ( σ o / ϵ ) ( a / ρ ′ ) ρ ^ ′ ⋅ d ρ ρ ^ ′ \Delta V = V(\rho)-V(a) = -\int_{a}^{\rho} (\sigma_o/\epsilon)(a/\rho')\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}'\cdot d\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}' ΔV=V(ρ)−V(a)=−∫aρ​(σo​/ϵ)(a/ρ′)ρ^​′⋅dρρ^​′

which simplifies to

V ( ρ ) = − ( σ o a / ϵ ) ∫ a ρ d ρ ′ / ρ ′ = − ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( ρ / a ) = ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( a / ρ ) V(\rho)= -(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\int_{a}^{\rho} d\rho'/\rho'=-(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(\rho/a)=(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(a/\rho) V(ρ)=−(σo​a/ϵ)∫aρ​dρ′/ρ′=−(σo​a/ϵ)ln(ρ/a)=(σo​a/ϵ)ln(a/ρ)

To compute the V V V for ρ > b \rho>b ρ>b, we need the potential at ρ = b \rho=b ρ=b, which is found by plugging this into the above equation

V ( b ) = ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( a / b ) V(b)=(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(a/b) V(b)=(σo​a/ϵ)ln(a/b)

For a < ρ < b a < \rho < b a<ρ<b, ( σ o / ϵ 0 ) ( a / ρ ) ρ ^ (\sigma_o/\epsilon_0)(a/\rho)\hat{\mathbf{\rho}} (σo​/ϵ0​)(a/ρ)ρ^​

V ( ρ ) − V ( b ) = − ∫ b ρ ( σ o / ϵ 0 ) ( a / ρ ′ ) ρ ^ ′ ⋅ d ρ ρ ^ ′ V(\rho)-V(b) = -\int_{b}^{\rho} (\sigma_o/\epsilon_0)(a/\rho')\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}'\cdot d\rho\hat{\mathbf{\rho}}' V(ρ)−V(b)=−∫bρ​(σo​/ϵ0​)(a/ρ′)ρ^​′⋅dρρ^​′

V ( ρ ) − ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( a / b ) = ( σ o a / ϵ 0 ) ln ⁡ ( b / ρ ) V(\rho)-(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(a/b) = (\sigma_oa/\epsilon_0)\ln(b/\rho) V(ρ)−(σo​a/ϵ)ln(a/b)=(σo​a/ϵ0​)ln(b/ρ)

V ( ρ ) = ( σ o a / ϵ 0 ) ln ⁡ ( b / ρ ) + ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( a / b ) V(\rho) = (\sigma_oa/\epsilon_0)\ln(b/\rho)+(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(a/b) V(ρ)=(σo​a/ϵ0​)ln(b/ρ)+(σo​a/ϵ)ln(a/b)

In summary,

  • V ( ρ ) = 0 V(\rho) = 0 V(ρ)=0 for ρ < a \rho < a ρ<a

  • V ( ρ ) = ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( a / ρ ) V(\rho) = (\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(a/\rho) V(ρ)=(σo​a/ϵ)ln(a/ρ) for a < ρ < b a < \rho < b a<ρ<b

  • V ( ρ ) = ( σ o a / ϵ 0 ) ln ⁡ ( b / ρ ) + ( σ o a / ϵ ) ln ⁡ ( a / b ) V(\rho) = (\sigma_oa/\epsilon_0)\ln(b/\rho)+(\sigma_oa/\epsilon)\ln(a/b) V(ρ)=(σo​a/ϵ0​)ln(b/ρ)+(σo​a/ϵ)ln(a/b) for ρ > b \rho>b ρ>b

It may not be obvious how to plot these lines, but the task is simplified by noting that V V V must be continuous and decreasing as one moves away from the charged cylinder. This is enough information to start a sketch. Note that one often sets the potential to zero at infinity. With a cylinder that is infinite in length, the potential is infinite at infinity. A similar issue occurs with infinite sheets of charge. |}

2.1.5 Dielectric Around Line of Charge

2.1.6 Dielectrics Around Shell of Charge

A spherical shell of radius a a a has a free surface density of σ 0 \sigma_0 σ0​ and is centered at the origin.

The shell is surrounded by a spherical dielectric with a dielectric constant ϵ 1 = 2 ϵ 0 \epsilon_1=2\epsilon_0 ϵ1​=2ϵ0​, inner radius a a a, and outer radius 2 a 2a 2a. Use Gauss’ Law for Dielectrics to

  1. Find equations for the electric field as a function of r r r.

  2. Plot the electric field as a function of r r r. Label important locations.

  3. Compute the bound polarization charge on the inner and outer surface of the dielectric.

(Above question is identical to HW problem except for part for computing potential has been removed and I have given a value for ϵ 1 \epsilon_1 ϵ1​)

A spherical shell of radius 2 a 2a 2a and a free surface density of − σ 0 -\sigma_0 −σ0​ is then placed around the dielectric.

4. Plot the electric field as a function of r r r. Label important locations. You do not need to show your work.

{| class=”wikitable collapsible collapsed” ! align=”left” | Answer |- | ∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

  • D = 0 \mathbf{D}=0 D=0 for r < a r<a r<a

  • D = σ 0 ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{D}=\sigma_0(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} D=σ0​(a2/r2)r^ for r > a r>a r>a

E = D / ϵ \mathbf{E}=\mathbf{D}/\epsilon E=D/ϵ

  • E = 0 \mathbf{E}=0 E=0 for r < a r<a r<a

  • E = ( σ 0 / ϵ 1 ) ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ = ( σ 0 / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) ) ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E}=(\sigma_0/\epsilon_1)(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}}=(\sigma_0/(2\epsilon_0))(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(σ0​/ϵ1​)(a2/r2)r^=(σ0​/(2ϵ0​))(a2/r2)r^ for a < r < 2 a a<r<2a a<r<2a

  • E = ( σ 0 / ϵ 0 ) ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E}=(\sigma_0/\epsilon_0)(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(σ0​/ϵ0​)(a2/r2)r^ for r > 2 a r>2a r>2a

Curve for a < r < 2 a a<r<2a a<r<2a starts at σ 0 / ( 2 ϵ 0 ) \sigma_0/(2\epsilon_0) σ0​/(2ϵ0​) and ends at σ 0 / ( 8 ϵ 0 ) \sigma_0/(8\epsilon_0) σ0​/(8ϵ0​)

Curve for r > 2 a r>2a r>2a starts at σ 0 / ( 4 ϵ 0 ) \sigma_0/(4\epsilon_0) σ0​/(4ϵ0​) and ends at 0.

Note that ϵ 1 = 2 ϵ 0 \epsilon_1=2\epsilon_0 ϵ1​=2ϵ0​ implies ϵ r = 2 \epsilon_r=2 ϵr​=2.

σ b = P ⋅ n ^ \sigma_b=\mathbf{P}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}} σb​=P⋅n^

and

P = ϵ 0 χ e E = ϵ 0 ( ϵ r − 1 ) E \mathbf{P} = \epsilon_0\chi_e\mathbf{E}=\epsilon_0(\epsilon_r-1)\mathbf{E} P=ϵ0​χe​E=ϵ0​(ϵr​−1)E

where ϵ r = ϵ / ϵ 0 \epsilon_r=\epsilon/\epsilon_0 ϵr​=ϵ/ϵ0​ so that

σ b = ϵ 0 ( ϵ r − 1 ) E ⋅ n ^ \sigma_b=\epsilon_0(\epsilon_r-1)\mathbf{E}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}} σb​=ϵ0​(ϵr​−1)E⋅n^

Normal to surface points outwards from volume, so at r = a r=a r=a, n ^ = − r ^ \hat{\mathbf{n}}=-\hat{\mathbf{r}} n^=−r^ and at r = b r=b r=b, n ^ = r ^ \hat{\mathbf{n}}=\hat{\mathbf{r}} n^=r^.

Inner surface at r = a r=a r=a, E = ( σ 0 / ϵ 1 ) ( a 2 / a 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E}=(\sigma_0/\epsilon_1)(a^2/a^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(σ0​/ϵ1​)(a2/a2)r^, so

σ b = ϵ 0 ( ϵ r − 1 ) ( σ 0 / ϵ 1 ) ( a 2 / a 2 ) r ^ ⋅ ( − r ^ ) = − σ 0 / 2 \sigma_b=\epsilon_0(\epsilon_r-1)(\sigma_0/\epsilon_1)(a^2/a^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}}\cdot(-\hat{\mathbf{r}})=-\sigma_0/2 σb​=ϵ0​(ϵr​−1)(σ0​/ϵ1​)(a2/a2)r^⋅(−r^)=−σ0​/2

Outer surface at r = b r=b r=b, E = ( σ 0 / ϵ 1 ) ( a 2 / ( 2 a ) 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E}=(\sigma_0/\epsilon_1)(a^2/(2a)^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(σ0​/ϵ1​)(a2/(2a)2)r^, so

σ b = ϵ 0 ( ϵ r − 1 ) ( σ 0 / ϵ 1 ) ( a 2 / ( 2 a ) 2 ) r ^ ⋅ r ^ = σ 0 / 8 \sigma_b=\epsilon_0(\epsilon_r-1)(\sigma_0/\epsilon_1)(a^2/(2a)^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{r}}=\sigma_0/8 σb​=ϵ0​(ϵr​−1)(σ0​/ϵ1​)(a2/(2a)2)r^⋅r^=σ0​/8

Check answers using Gauss’ Law

∮ S E ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S / ϵ 0 \oint_{S} \mathbf{E}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S}/\epsilon_0 ∮S​E⋅da=QInside,S​/ϵ0​

with the computed bound charges included in Q I n s i d e , S Q_{Inside,S} QInside,S​ and the computed values of E \mathbf{E} E for each region. Draw a Gaussian sphere in dielectric and then outside of dielectric and verify that Gauss’ Law is satisfied for both cases.

When outer shell is added, only modification is for r > 2 a r>2a r>2a

∮ S D ⋅ d a = Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e \oint_{S}\mathbf{D}\cdot d\mathbf{a} = Q_{Inside,S,free} ∮S​D⋅da=QInside,S,free​

The free charges are on the surfaces at r = a r=a r=a and r = 2 a r=2a r=2a,

Q I n s i d e , S , f r e e = 4 π a 2 σ 0 − 4 π ( 2 a ) 2 σ 0 = − 12 π σ 0 Q_{Inside,S,free}=4\pi a^2 \sigma_0 - 4\pi (2a)^2 \sigma_0 = -12\pi\sigma_0 QInside,S,free​=4πa2σ0​−4π(2a)2σ0​=−12πσ0​

so that

D = − 3 σ 0 ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{D}=-3\sigma_0(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} D=−3σ0​(a2/r2)r^

E = − 3 ( σ 0 / ϵ 0 ) ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E}=-3(\sigma_0/\epsilon_0)(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=−3(σ0​/ϵ0​)(a2/r2)r^

Note that I accepted E = 0 \mathbf{E}=0 E=0 as an answer in case you were assuming that the charge on the outer shell equaled the charge on the inner shell, which is a common type of problem and easy to miss if you are working quickly. |}

2.1.7 Dielectrics Around Sphere of Charge

A solid sphere of charge with radius a a a and uniform charge density ρ o \rho_o ρo​ is surrounded by three materials, each with a different permittivity. A cross-section of the sphere is shown.

  1. Compute and plot E ( r ) E(r) E(r).

  2. Compute V ( 2 a ) − V ( a ) V(2a)-V(a) V(2a)−V(a).

  3. Compute all bound surface charge densities, σ b \sigma_b σb​.

  4. Compute all bound volume charge densities, ρ b \rho_b ρb​.

Write all of your answers and label your plot at appropriate points in terms of ρ o , ϵ o , \rho_o, \epsilon_o, ρo​,ϵo​, and a a a.

{| class=”wikitable collapsible collapsed” ! align=”left” | Answer |- | D D D and E E E are in r ^ \hat{\mathbf{r}} r^ direction.

  • D = ρ o ( 4 / 3 ) π r 3 / ( 4 π r 2 ) \mathbf{D}=\rho_o (4/3)\pi r^3/(4\pi r^2) D=ρo​(4/3)πr3/(4πr2) for r < a r<a r<a

  • E = ( ρ o / 2 ϵ o ) ( 4 / 3 ) π a 3 / ( 4 π r 2 ) r ^ = ( E o / 2 ) ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E} =(\rho_o/2\epsilon_o) (4/3)\pi a^3/(4\pi r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}}=(E_o/2)(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(ρo​/2ϵo​)(4/3)πa3/(4πr2)r^=(Eo​/2)(a2/r2)r^ for a < r < 2 a a<r<2a a<r<2a

  • E = ( ρ o / 4 ϵ o ) ( 4 / 3 ) π a 3 / ( 4 π r 2 ) r ^ = ( E o / 4 ) ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E} =(\rho_o/4\epsilon_o) (4/3)\pi a^3/(4\pi r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}}=(E_o/4)(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(ρo​/4ϵo​)(4/3)πa3/(4πr2)r^=(Eo​/4)(a2/r2)r^ for 3 a < r < 4 a 3a<r<4a 3a<r<4a

  • E = ( ρ o / ϵ o ) ( 4 / 3 ) π a 3 / ( 4 π r 2 ) r ^ = E o ( a 2 / r 2 ) r ^ \mathbf{E} =(\rho_o/\epsilon_o) (4/3)\pi a^3/(4\pi r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}}=E_o(a^2/r^2)\hat{\mathbf{r}} E=(ρo​/ϵo​)(4/3)πa3/(4πr2)r^=Eo​(a2/r2)r^ for r > 4 a r>4a r>4a

where E o ≡ ( ρ o a / 3 ϵ o ) E_o \equiv (\rho_oa/3\epsilon_o) Eo​≡(ρo​a/3ϵo​).

2.1.8 Dielectrics around a Point Charge

{| style=”margin-bottom:1em” cellpadding=”2” width=”100%” align=”left” |- |style=”vertical-align:top” width=”40%” | A positive point charge is at the origin. Three spherical dielectrics are also centered on the origin. They have

  1. Inner radius a a a, outer radius 2 a 2a 2a, and ϵ = 2 ϵ o \epsilon=2\epsilon_o ϵ=2ϵo​

  2. Inner radius 2 a 2a 2a, outer radius 3 a 3a 3a, and ϵ = 4 ϵ o \epsilon=4\epsilon_o ϵ=4ϵo​

  3. Inner radius 3 a 3a 3a, outer radius 4 a 4a 4a, and ϵ = 2 ϵ o \epsilon=2\epsilon_o ϵ=2ϵo​

2.1.9 Dielectric Between Spherical Shells of Charge

2.1.10 General Rule for Computing E \mathbf{E} E?

You may find after solving a few dielectric problems using Gauss’ Law that it seems as if the electric field in the dielectric is always simply E i n   d i e l e c t r i c = E o / ϵ r \mathbf{E}_{in\text{ }dielectric}=\mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon_r Ein dielectric​=Eo​/ϵr​, where E o \mathbf{E}_o Eo​ is the electric field that would exist if the dielectric was not there.

For elementary problems involving dielectrics, this is often true. For example:

  1. One or more large square dielectrics between two large sheets of charge

  2. One or more large square dielectrics between two large capacitor plates ‘’’after’’’ they are disconnected from a battery (so problem is equivalent to 1.)

    1. and 2. for one or more dielectrics between two co-aligned and long cylindrical shells

    1. and 2. for one or more dielectrics between two co-aligned and spherical shells

Incidentally, 1.-4. are all problems for which Gauss’ Law for dielectrics can be used to find D \mathbf{D} D and E \mathbf{E} E.

In general, however, E i n , d i e l e c t r i c ≠ E o / ϵ r \mathbf{E}_{in,dielectric}\ne\mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon_r Ein,dielectric​=Eo​/ϵr​. Two examples:

  1. A large square dielectric between large capacitor plates that are held at a constant potential, V o V_o Vo​. The presence of the dielectric causes the amount of charge on the capacitor plates to increase. The electric field in the dielectric is E o / ? \mathbf{E}_o/? Eo​/? and not E o / ϵ \mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon Eo​/ϵ, where E o = V o / d E_o=V_o/d Eo​=Vo​/d is the electric field that existed before. This problem is covered in the section on capacitors with dielectrics.

  2. A spherical dielectric in a constant electric field, E o \mathbf{E}_o Eo​. In this situation, the induced polarization adds up in a way so that the net electric field is E o / ? \mathbf{E}_o/? Eo​/? instead of E o / ϵ \mathbf{E}_o/\epsilon Eo​/ϵ inside the dielectric. This problem is covered in the section on boundary value problems with dielectrics.
